Four human coronaviruses have been established as endemic: HCoV-NL63, HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, and HCoV-HKU1. These endemic strains have been identified as significant causes of acute respiratory infection and the common cold, causing 15% to 30% of respiratory tract infections each year.

The outbreak of SARS in China in 2002 to 2003 highlighted the potential of these and/or related viruses to cause outbreaks of severe disease, because more than 8000 cases were diagnosed with close to a 10% case fatality rate.
